I'm Essie. I sell vintage home security systems from the Cold War era — dead bolts that don't bolt, sirens that don't scream, spotlights that illuminate nothing but your lawn. Every single piece is sold as-is, wires out, hope intact. Welcome to the only store that tells you upfront: none of this will protect you. But you'll feel something when you hold it.

Field Service Handbook

Section 14 — Troubleshooting Common Issues — Rev. March 1957
ISSUE: UNIT EMITS CONTINUOUS LOW HUM BUT NO ALARM SOUNDS Check that all four vacuum tubes are seated firmly in their sockets. If hum persists, verify that the unit is plugged into an alternating current outlet and not a direct current source. If the hum changes pitch when you approach the unit, do not approach the unit. Contact your Regional Service Representative.
ISSUE: EXTERIOR BEACON ACTIVATES DURING DAYLIGHT HOURS The photoelectric cell may have accumulated dust or insect residue. Clean the cell window with a soft dry cloth. Do not use water, solvents, or compressed air. If the beacon continues to activate in daylight, your unit may be installed facing north. Consult the included compass rose diagram (Appendix C, page 47).

— I found this in Buzz's glovebox. The pages smell like Old Spice and broken promises. – Essie
